title-group.article-title: An Overview of Administrative and National Survey Databases for Use in Otolaryngology Research

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, Armstrong Institute for Patient Safety and Quality, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland, USA
2Division of Otolaryngology, Children's National Medical Center, George Washington University Medical Center, Washington, DC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Emily F. Boss, MD, MPH, Department of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery, Division of Pediatric Otolaryngology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, 601 N. Caroline St, 6th Floor, Baltimore, MD 21287, USA Email: erudnic2@jhmi.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © American Academy of Otolaryngology—Head and Neck Surgery Foundation 2013
permissions.copyright-holder: Official journal of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery Foundation

abstract.p: An emerging focus on measurement and reporting of health care quality indicators calls for a sound evidence base that otolaryngologists can use to support clinical care decisions. In addition to traditional clinical trials, practitioners are heeding results of high-quality comparative-effectiveness and health services research analyses to better understand the complexity of disease epidemiology, care variation, health care costs, and surgical utilization for common conditions. Many national publicly available data sources exist for use in clinical research that may be of benefit for the academic and clinical otolaryngologist. The strength and value of these sources vary depending on the intended use or research question. The purpose of this commentary is to introduce and provide an overview of some major national and administrative databases, highlight potential strengths and limitations of these data, and suggest applications for use in advancing the care of our patients in otolaryngology.

body.p: Producing high quality clinical research in surgical specialties is an ongoing challenge. There are many limitations related to cost, ethics, and recruitment in performing traditional randomized controlled or even prospective trials to evaluate the overall efficacy of surgical procedures. Within otolaryngology, much of the current evidence base relies on observational cohort studies, sometimes retrospective, which are most frequently conducted within single institutions using relatively small and local patient populations. Although these studies offer important individual contributions to our knowledge of otolaryngic diseases, the pursuit for more collective, higher-powered, and better quality research for our field remains at times elusive. This pursuit is strengthened by the current health care climate’s push to reward patient-centered, evidence-based medicine delivered by subspecialists.

To study disease and surgical procedures on a population level, researchers in many specialties employ detailed health services research analyses to investigate effects that cannot be clearly measured through traditional patient-based clinical research. There are a multitude of publicly available databases that may be used toward this end, some of which could have particular relevance for research in otolaryngology and surgery. These databases may rely on nationally distributed surveys or administrative data collected by a variety of methods. Although useful and informative, these data may often seem inaccessible and overwhelming. The objectives of this commentary are to describe key uses of national and administrative data in clinical research, provide an overview of some commonly used pediatric databases, and highlight strengths and limitations of using these data to answer clinical questions. This commentary is meant to serve as an overview and not a comprehensive review; interested investigators are encouraged to directly contact the authors or database administrators for specific questions regarding their own research. Furthermore, this brief introduction is derived from the authors’ experience, and we caution that the content and governance of these databases are often times in flux and evolving.

sec.title: Why Do We Use Survey or Administrative Data?
sec.p: Administrative data have several unique and powerful applications in both health services research and also in clinical quality improvement. In contrast to single-institution cohort studies, these data can be used toward epidemiologic investigations, where disease prevalence, procedural incidence, or geographical variation is more broadly investigated. Several sources use national surveys that are weighted to represent either the overall US child and adolescent population or the overall US health care visit/encounter distribution, thus allowing nationwide estimations. Other sources rely on administrative data reported by a collective group of hospitals.

National or administrative data can be used to more closely study health service utilization. An investigator may evaluate quantity of ordered laboratory/radiographic tests or procedures performed per discharge, perhaps specifically to look at overuse or variability among providers, institutions, and regions. Similarly, these data can be powerful for investigation into health disparities pertaining to utilization of services, as basic demographics for each patient discharged are often provided at some level, such as age, sex, race/ethnicity, and insurance. Administrative data can evaluate relationships of these different variables, for example, how specific demographics, diagnoses, or procedures are related to resource utilization.

Administrative databases often include variables related to comorbid conditions or outcomes. Through these data, an investigator might identify macro-level trends that cannot simply be identified in single institution studies. Furthermore, aggregate data can help with magnifying disease trends from an epidemiologic standpoint.

Administrative data may also help identify important mechanisms related to clinical quality improvement. They may allow research into adherence to evidence-based clinical care guidelines. Administrative data are a common source of investigation into health care costs. However, databases typically supply actual charges with perhaps a cost-to-charge ratio for the facility. Additional quality indicators that may be identified through various national or administrative data include variables such as length of stay, length of procedure/recovery, or readmission for a particular diagnosis.

Table 1 summarizes some common uses of national survey or administrative data in health services research and clinical quality improvement. Table 2 identifies strengths and weaknesses for use of national survey or administrative data in evaluating clinical questions.

caption.p: Common Uses for Survey or Administrative Data in Pediatric Health Services Research

tr.td: Disease prevalence
Procedural incidence
Geographic variation
Demographic rates and variation
Laboratory or radiology tests
Prescriptions and medication orders
Procedural volumes
Seasonal variation and trends
Charges (not costs) for specific processes or procedures
Charges associated with comorbid conditions, factors, and outcomes
Charge variability by provider, institution, or region
Length of stay
Readmissions
Time-to-procedure
Utilization before/after procedure
Clinical guideline adherence (tests ordered and use of resources)

caption.p: General Strengths and Limitations of National Survey and Administrative Data Use in Clinical and Health Services Research

tr.td: High power
Patient-level data
Weighted/representative of US population (true for national databases)
Variation between hospitals (common for administrative databases)
Longitudinal data analysis (PHIS, Medicaid)
Rare diagnoses can be studied across multiple facilities
Cross-sectional or retrospective, or focusing only on single admission/procedure
ICD-9/ICD-10 coding is variable (high specificity, low sensitivity)
Focuses on single admission or procedure, so inability to follow patient over time (may be different with PHIS)
Do not see outcomes of treatment
Estimates charges, not costs
Variability in risk adjustment of hospitals
Risk stratification may not be robust/case mix index may not be appropriate
May cost money to use

fn.p: Abbreviations: ICD-9, International Classification of Diseases, 9th Revision; ICD-10, International Classification of Diseases, 10th Revision; PHIS, Pediatric Health Information System.

sec.title: Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project (HCUP): http://www.hcup-us.ahrq.gov/overview.jsp
sec.p: Included in this broad aggregation of hospital administrative data, which is sponsored by the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality (AHRQ), are the Nationwide Inpatient Sample (NIS), which includes inpatient data (all ages) from a national sample of over 1000 hospitals, and the Kids Inpatient Database (KID), which is a nationwide sample of pediatric discharges.1 These databases are perhaps the most commonly used in surgical specialties. The Nationwide Emergency Department Sample (NEDS) is another HCUP national database. In addition, HCUP is inclusive of several other databases, often state specific, such as the State Ambulatory Surgery Databases (SASD) or State Emergency Department Databases (SEDD).

Data elements included in NIS, KID, and other HCUP databases are extremely detailed and expansive. Data are collected based on hospital encounters or visits and do not include individual patient identifiers. Use of these data is strongly enhanced with statistical consultation to appropriately access the data and to help provide an understanding of the implications of the data. Many varying hypotheses can be tested, and longitudinal trends in cost and resource utilization can be examined for specific disease codes. A notable advantage in use of HCUP databases is that data from the national sites (NIS, KID, NEDS) are weighted so that national estimates can be performed.

sec.title: Medicaid: http://www.medicaid.gov
sec.p: Medicaid, in addition to the expanded Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), provides health care to over 40 million children in the United States, over half of whom live in low-income settings.2 Medicaid and CHIP are programs of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. Analysis of Medicaid and CHIP claims data can provide insightful, patient-specific analyses for children with preidentified diagnoses. Medicaid claims data are powerful for longitudinally assessing health service utilization and medication usage for low-income children, potentially before or after a specific procedure, but they cannot easily be used to interpret clinical decision making or health outcomes. Medicaid and CHIP data are typically accessed at the state level. The ResDAC (Research Data Assistance Center) is available for detailed questions regarding use, administration, and access to Medicaid and individual state CHIP data. The ResDAC also provides the Medicaid Analytic eXtract data files (MAX), which are national versions of the Medicaid data.

sec.title: Pediatric Health Information System
sec.p: The Pediatric Health Information System (PHIS) is produced by the Children’s Hospital Association (formerly named the Child Health Corporation of America). The PHIS contains data from 43 large freestanding children’s hospitals across North America, detailing records of a variety of encounters such as inpatient admissions, ambulatory surgical cases, or emergency department visits.3 Data are entered from medical records and billing systems on a quarterly basis. A particular advantage to use of PHIS data is that investigators can perform longitudinal data analysis using unique patient identifiers. A limitation of PHIS data is that it represents a “convenience sample” and is not weighted or nationally representative. Moreover, use is limited only to employees of the 43 participating hospitals (contact phis@childrenshospital.org).

sec.title: American College of Surgeons National Trauma Data Bank: http://www.facs.org/trauma/ntdb/index.html
sec.p: This registry of perhaps the most comprehensive collection of trauma data in our country provides tremendous opportunity for our specialty to use a longstanding, sophisticated database to analyze trends in trauma.4 Data are collected through specific abstraction forms specifically created for the purpose of this registry; these data are not used for administrative purposes. Governance of access to this platform is via the National Trauma Data Bank and the American College of Surgeons. For those interested in solely trauma conditions or outcomes, this comprehensive platform is worthy of inquiry.

sec.title: American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP): http://site.acsnsqip.org/about/
sec.p: This extensive database has emerged as a powerful platform to aggregate patient outcomes and to identify quality improvement opportunities. Sentinel successful work in the Veterans Administration hospitals almost 2 decades prior demonstrating improvement in hospitals that were outliers based on the NSQIP methodology led to the extrapolation of this platform to adults and now to pediatric hospitals.5-7 ACS NSQIP is actually a quality abstraction program where data is abstracted from cases of participating hospitals, and is not designed per se for administrative use. Access to the data from NSQIP is coordinated and can be approached via contacting the NSQIP administrators. Of note, otolaryngology is the first surgical specialty to launch a pilot data collection within the NSQIP Pediatric program. In addition to collecting standard quality, morbidity, and mortality outcomes related to otolaryngic procedures, the pediatric otolaryngology pilot assesses specialty-specific outcomes related to airway reconstruction, otologic procedures, neck abscesses, and tracheotomy. Preliminary data will be available from this pilot in July 2013.

sec.title: Surveys and Data Collection Systems of the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS): http://www.cdc.gov/nchs/surveys.htm
sec.p: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Health Statistics is the principal agency monitoring health statistics in the United States. The NCHS acquires data using multiple methods, including personal/household survey or interviews, provider interviews, acquisition of birth and death certificates, standardized physical examinations, and use of medical and laboratory records. The NCHS data are markedly different from what is acquired through administrative claims or registry data. The NCHS collects information on a wide array of health indicators and patient populations to inform current public health priorities and initiatives. Data collected by the NCHS are strategically sampled to broadly and equally sample either the US population or US distribution of health care visits/encounters, and therefore are weighted to be nationally representative.

The NCHS sponsors a variety of surveys; some surveys are still active, and some are complete but still useful and accessible.8 Certain provider-based surveys (which evaluate medical visits/encounters), such as the National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS) or the National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NAMCS), may be more useful for surgical specialists. In addition, the National Survey of Ambulatory Surgery (NSAS) has provided national data on ambulatory surgical encounters in the United States (1994-1996 and 2006).
The NCHS data are accessible to the public through public use data files. More detailed data can be accessed securely through NCHS Research Data Centers.

sec.title: Medical Expenditure Panel Survey (MEPS): http://meps.ahrq.gov/mepsweb/
sec.p: The AHRQ administers the Medical Expenditure Panel Survey, which is geared toward data collection on health services, health care costs, and insurance coverage. The MEPS surveys families, health care providers, and employers.9 There are 2 major components to the MEPS: a household component and an insurance component. Although MEPS has been less commonly employed in pediatric surgical research, this survey contains powerful information related to pediatric health care use, conditions, and expenses that could bear great significance in otolaryngology.

sec.title: Hospital Compare: http://www.medicare.gov/hospitalcompare
sec.p: Hospital Compare is a publicly available website from the US government (in part under the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services) and focuses solely on Medicare-certified hospitals. The intent of this freely accessible platform is for consumers/patients to find out how the hospital from which they will receive care compares with other Medicare hospitals on specific metrics. Moreover, the broader goal of Hospital Compare is to provide impetus for inclusive hospitals to improve the quality of care they deliver and ultimately to improve outcomes for patients. The metrics that are tracked and reported upon are varied and run the spectrum of care from process-of-care measures to complications to spending per admission. The Department of Health and Human Services is attentive to the need to study this data set and offers access via contacting the site administrators (HospitalCompare@hsag.com).
Tables 3 and 4 provide quick reference guides to the above listed database information.

caption.p: Key Administrative Databases for Use in Otolaryngology: Quick Reference

tr.td: Healthcare Cost and Utilization Project
NIS, KID, NEDS, SASD, SEDD, and others
Data collected based on hospital visits; no individual patient identifiers; weighted data to represent the United States
Medicaid
Statewide CHIP; National MAX
Individual patient claims data; represents over 40 million children in the United States; applicable for longitudinal health service utilization trends; typically data accessible by state
Pediatric Health Information System
Accessible only to employees of 43 participating hospitals: http://www.chca.com/owner_hospitals/index.html; contactphis@childrenshospital.org

Records from 43 large freestanding children’s hospitals in the United States; detailed information from inpatient, ambulatory surgical, emergency room settings; represents a “convenience sample” of hospitals
American College of Surgeons (ACS) National Trauma Data Bank*
Analysis of trends in trauma and trauma surgery–related conditions and procedures; governed by the ACS and National Trauma Data Bank
American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (NSQIP)*
NSQIP Pediatric

Largest quality initiative put forth by the discipline of surgery; evaluates surgical procedural rates and outcomes; NSQIP Pediatric data should be publicly available during this calendar year; otolaryngology pilot outcomes data for specific procedures pending

fn.p: Abbreviations: CHIP, Children’s Health Insurance Program; KID, Kids Inpatient Database; NIS, Nationwide Inpatient Sample; SASD, State Ambulatory Surgery Databases; SEDD, State Emergency Department Databases. *ACS NTDB is a trauma registry; ACS NSQIP is a quality abstraction program. These data are collected for quality improvement and not for administrative purposes.

caption.p: Key National Survey Databases for Use in Otolaryngology: Quick Reference

tr.td: Surveys and Data Collection Systems of the National Center for Health Statistics
NHANES, NHAMCS, NAMCS, NSAS, and others

Statistical branch of the CDC; survey-based data (not claims based) with multiple data acquisition mechanisms: personal/household survey or interview, provider interview, birth/death certificates, physical examinations, medical/laboratory records; sampled so that United States is represented (weighted data); accessible through public use data files
Medical Expenditure Panel Survey
Administered by AHRQ; directed at measurement of health services, cost, insurance coverage; household and insurance survey components exist
Hospital Compare

Publicly available website hosted by CMS; available for patients to view quality indicators so they may make informed choices in Medicare hospitals; “Physician Compare” website is currently following suit

fn.p: Abbreviations: AHRQ, Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality; CDC, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; CMS, Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services; NAMCS, National Ambulatory Medical Care Survey; NHAMCS, National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey; NHANES, National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey; NSAS, National Survey of Ambulatory Surgery.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This commentary summarizes commonly used major administrative and national survey databases that could be applicable for use in otolaryngology research; indeed, a search by the reader will reveal that the majority of the databases discussed herein have been used for otolaryngology research. Prior to use of any of these databases, we encourage the investigator to contact the source data administrators to understand strengths and limitations as well as analytic considerations specific to the data in question. Appropriate application of these data in clinical research can provide important macro-level contributions that will further the quality of research in our specialty.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Emily F. Boss, conceived and designed article, drafted article, final approval of version to be published; Rahul K. Shah, co-conceived and designed article, co-drafted article, final approval of version to be published.

sec.title: Disclosures
sec.p: Competing interests: None.

Sponsorships: The creation of this manuscript was supported by the Safety and Quality Committee of the American Society of Pediatric Otolaryngology. Content reflects a summary of the authors and not the individual data sources described.
Funding source: None.
